pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3 (P3)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 352, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 495, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 525]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 571]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Expand \(\frac{16}{(2 + x)^2}\) in ascending powers of \(x\), up to and including the term in \(x^2\), simplifying the coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 155, 94, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(y = \frac{\mathrm{e}^{2x}}{1 + \mathrm{e}^{2x}}\). Show that the gradient of the curve at the point for which \(x = \ln 3\) is \(\frac{9}{50}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 227, 96, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 227, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
(i) Express \(8 \cos \theta + 15 \sin \theta\) in the form \(R \cos (\theta - \alpha)\), where \(R > 0\) and \(0^\circ < \alpha < 90^\circ\). Give the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 243, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 273, 153, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 272, 920, 292]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(8 \cos \theta + 15 \sin \theta = 12\), giving all solutions in the interval \(0^\circ < \theta < 360^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 288, 920, 307]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 335, 96, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
During an experiment, the number of organisms present at time \(t\) days is denoted by \(N\), where \(N\) is treated as a continuous variable. It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 375, 583, 406]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}N}{\mathrm{d}t} = 1.2\mathrm{e}^{-0.02t}N^{0.5}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 541, 432]]<|/det|>
When \(t = 0\), the number of organisms present is 100.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 444, 153, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 467, 463]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(N\) in terms of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 475, 153, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 475, 740, 494]]<|/det|>
State what happens to the number of organisms present after a long time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 528, 96, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 667, 559]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\int_{1}^{a} x \ln x \, \mathrm{d}x = 22\), where \(a\) is a constant greater than 1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 570, 156, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 567, 400, 604]]<|/det|>
Show that \(a = \sqrt{\left(\frac{87}{2\ln a - 1}\right)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 577, 920, 596]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 613, 153, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 613, 920, 648]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula based on the equation in part (i) to find the value of \(a\) correct to 2 decimal places. Use an initial value of 6 and give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 675, 96, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 510, 694]]<|/det|>
The complex number \(w\) is defined by \(w = - 1 + \mathrm{i}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 707, 153, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 707, 715, 726]]<|/det|>
Find the modulus and argument of \(w^2\) and \(w^3\), showing your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 707, 920, 726]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 739, 153, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 739, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
The points in an Argand diagram representing \(w\) and \(w^2\) are the ends of a diameter of a circle. Find the equation of the circle, giving your answer in the form \(|z - (a + bi)| = k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 755, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 395, 93]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 98, 598, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{p}(x) = a x^{3} - x^{2} + 4x - a,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 125, 631, 145]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is a constant. It is given that \((2x - 1)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 157, 151, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 157, 514, 176]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\) and hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 158, 920, 176]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 195, 153, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 191, 757, 217]]<|/det|>
When \(a\) has the value found in part (i), express \(\frac{8x - 13}{\mathrm{p}(x)}\) in partial fractions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 247, 96, 266]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 255, 764, 496]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 515, 567, 534]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with parametric equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 541, 641, 561]]<|/det|>
\[x = \sin t + \cos t,\quad y = \sin^{3}t + \cos^{3}t,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 248, 588]]<|/det|>
for \(\frac{1}{4}\pi < t < \frac{5}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 604, 156, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 603, 391, 631]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = -3 \sin t \cos t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 606, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 642, 153, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 641, 504, 660]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the origin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 643, 920, 661]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 673, 153, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 673, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(t\) for which the gradient of the curve is 1, giving your answers correct to 2 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 689, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 749, 94, 768]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 740, 920, 797]]<|/det|>
The line \(l\) has equation \(\mathbf{r} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 1 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} + \lambda \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 3 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}\), where \(a\) is a constant. The plane \(p\) has equation \(2x - 2y + z = 10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 809, 153, 827]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 809, 608, 828]]<|/det|>
Given that \(l\) does not lie in \(p\), show that \(l\) is parallel to \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 809, 920, 828]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 840, 153, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 840, 479, 858]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\) for which \(l\) lies in \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 840, 920, 858]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 871, 151, 889]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 871, 823, 890]]<|/det|>
It is now given that the distance between \(l\) and \(p\) is 6. Find the possible values of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 871, 920, 890]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
